1714603534692.description: This class starts with a discussion of mathematical logic. Logic is the basis of all mathematical reasoning, and of all automated reasoning. It has practical applications to the design of computing machines, to the specification of systems, to artificial intelligence, to computer programming, to programming languages, and to other areas of computer science, as well as to many other fields of study.  Discrete Structures: students will be able to work with discrete structures, which are the abstract mathematical structures used to represent discrete objects and relationships between these objects. These discrete structures include sets, permutations, relations, graphs, and trees. Next is Combinatorial Analysis: an important problem-solving skill is the ability to count or enumerate objects. The discussion of enumeration in this book begins with the basic techniques of counting. The stress is on performing combinatorial analysis to solve counting problems and analyze algorithms, not on applying formulae. Certain classes of problems are solved by the specification of an algorithm. After an algorithm has been described, a computer program can be constructed implementing it. The mathematical portions of this activity, which include the specification of the algorithm, the verification that it works properly are all covered in this course.
1714603534692.title: Discrete mathematics

1714604345153.description: Differential Equations are among the important subjects in mathematics which are essential for analysis and solving various problems in the natural sciences, engineering, economics and so on. In addition to learning basic techniques of solving first and second-order differential equations and system of linear ODEs, we will also study their applications to mathematical physics, mathematics and other fields.

1714605085997.description: The course is devoted to understanding the mathematical aspects of classical Newtonian mechanics. In this course we derive Newton's laws of motion from the variational principle, obtain conservation laws from Noether's theorem, examine a two-body problem and small oscillations from the perspective of the dynamical systems theory. The Hamiltonian formulation of the laws of mechanics will be briefly presented at the end of the course.

reading_list.authors: L. D. Landau and E. M. Lifshitz
reading_list.title: Mechanics (3rd edition)

reading_list.authors: H. Goldstein, C. P. Poole, J. L. Safko
reading_list.title: Classical Mechanics

1714605085997.title: Classical mechanics

course_plan.topics: The primary goal of mathematical statistics. General set and sample. Variation set and statistical series. Selective numerical characteristics: mathematical expectation, dispersion, ets.
Grouped data. All characteristics. Histogram
Classic, geometric, statistic definitions of probability. Formulas of addition and multiplication formulas of probabilities.
Conditional probability. Independent events. Formulas of total probability and Bayes. Curcits
Random values. Law of distribution, function of distribution and its properties. Discrete random values. Operations over random values.
Special Discrete Distributions. Bernully formula. The most probable number of successes in n tests of Bernully Approached formula of Poisson. Muavre-Laplace theorem
Continuous Random Variables. Probability Density Functions. Variance of a random value and its properties. Other numerical characteristics of random values. The normal law of distribution.
Midterm / Special Continuous Distributions. Uniform Random Variable. Exponential Random Variable. The normal law of distribution.
Special Continuous Distributions. Uniform Random Variable. Exponential Random Variable. The normal law of distribution.

Sampling Distributions. Mean and Standard Deviation of X (x-bar); Sampling Distributions of proportion p;  Sampling Distributions of sample variance; Limit Theorems. Markov and Chebyshev Inequalities. Laws of Large Numbers.More Expectations and Variances.
Limit Theorems. Markov and Chebyshev Inequalities. Laws of Large Numbers.More Expectations and Variances.
Method of confidential intervals. Confidential interval for a mathematical expectation and variance of normal general set.
Covariance. Correlation.
Covariance. Correlation. End term
Pearson's criterion. Review. Preparation for final exam

Estimations of unknown parameters

1715797549561.description: Complex Analysis is a subject that is extremely useful in many applied topics such as numerical analysis, electrical engineering, mathematical physics, chaos theory, and much more, and you will see some of these applications throughout the course. This course provides an introduction to complex analysis which is the theory of complex functions of a complex variable. We will start by introducing the complex numbers, complex plane, along with the algebra and geometry, and then we will make our way via differentiation, power series representation Laurent series, integration, Cauchy's theorem, residue calculus

1715798828341.description: Purpose of this course is to provide the students, the future computer modeling and simulation scientist, and engineers with numerical methods of computational modeling and a seamless approach to numerical algorithms for solving of a typical engineering and applied mathematics problems. Course covers the different numerical methods and will focus on a base material of numerical methods of applied mathematics and analysis. Students will familiarize with following topics: computer algorithms, polynomial and spline interpolation, functional methods of data approximation, numerical integration, iterative methods for solving linear systems and nonlinear equations, numerical methods for solving ordinary and partial differential equations.

reading_list.authors: P Richard L. Burden, J. Douglas Faires.
reading_list.title: Numerical Analysis.
Lectures in basic computational numerical analysis

1715798828341.title: Numerical methods

1715799921238.description: Linear algebra is the branch of mathematics concerning linear equations, linear maps  and their representations in  vector spaces and through matrices. Linear algebra is central to almost all areas of mathematics.  Analytic geometry, also called coordinate geometry, mathematical subject in which algebraic symbolism and methods  are used to represent and solve problems in geometry.  The importance of analytic geometry is that it establishes a  correspondence between geometric curves and algebraic equations. Student can use the knowledge of the given  course in order to construct the mathematical models in economy and business.

reading_list.title: Сборник  задач по  аналитическо  й геометрии

1715799921238.title: Linear Algebra and Analytic Geometry

1715800450448.description: This course covers some of the main practical aspects of programming, and serves as a continuation of the introduction to programming class. The topics discussed include Object-Oriented programming, GUI programming, data structures, networking, multithreading, and so on. Java is used as the programming language. Flipped classroom practices such as online video lectures, group work activities during classes, peer reviewing, etc. are planned to be included. Small-size projects considered to facilitate project-based learning

reading_list.title: Introduction to Java Programming (Comprehensive version, 10th edition)

57832583838464.description: The course Calculus 2 deals with the most basic concepts in analysis. The goal of the course is to acquaint the students with rigorous proofs in analysis and also to set a firm foundation for calculus of one variable. The course consists of concepts such as sets, functions, sequences and their limits, series of numbers, tests for convergence, concepts of alternating series, absolute and conditional convergence, power series. Taylor’s series, the study of functions using the methods of differential calculus.

reading_list.title: Basic Analysis I. Introduction to Real Analysis, Volume I

57832583838464.title: Mathematical analysis 2
